title: Inclusion and Justice
shortSummary: Isaiah 56 emphasizes God's call for justice and righteousness, promising blessings to those who keep His covenant, including eunuchs and foreigners. The chapter also warns against unfaithful leaders and highlights God's plan to gather all His people, extending His salvation beyond Israel.
timeline: c. 8th century BC - Isaiah's prophetic ministry during the divided kingdom period

keyCharacters.name: The LORD
keyCharacters.description: The sovereign God who commands justice, promises salvation, and gathers His people.

keyCharacters.name: The Eunuchs
keyCharacters.description: Individuals traditionally excluded from full participation in Israel’s community, here promised an everlasting name if they keep God’s covenant.

keyCharacters.name: The Sons of the Stranger
keyCharacters.description: Foreigners who join themselves to the LORD and keep His covenant, welcomed into His house and worship.

keyCharacters.name: The Watchmen
keyCharacters.description: Unfaithful leaders and priests criticized for their ignorance, greed, and failure to guard the people.

definitions.definition: The seventh day of the week set apart by God for rest and worship, a sign of covenant relationship.
A man who is castrated or otherwise unable to have children, often excluded from full religious participation in Israel.
A solemn agreement between God and His people involving commitments and promises.
A place dedicated to worship and prayer, here described as open to all peoples, not just Israel.

outline.heading: Call to Justice and Righteousness
outline.description: God commands His people to uphold justice and keep the Sabbath holy, promising that His salvation and righteousness are near.

outline.heading: Inclusion of Eunuchs and Foreigners
outline.description: God assures eunuchs and foreigners who keep His covenant that they will receive a lasting name and a place in His house, emphasizing the inclusiveness of His salvation.

outline.heading: Warning Against Unfaithful Leaders
outline.description: God condemns the watchmen—leaders and priests—who are blind, greedy, and neglect their duties, indulging themselves rather than caring for the people.

application: Commit to practicing justice and righteousness in daily life as a reflection of God’s coming salvation.
Embrace and welcome all who sincerely seek God, recognizing that His covenant extends beyond ethnic Israel.
Guard against spiritual complacency and greed, especially in leadership and service to the church.
Honor God's appointed times of rest and worship, such as the Sabbath, as a sign of faithfulness.

keyVerses.text: Thus saith the LORD, Keep ye judgment, and do justice: for my salvation is near to come, and my righteousness to be revealed.
keyVerses.significance: This verse sets the tone for the chapter, calling believers to live justly in light of God's imminent salvation.

keyVerses.text: Even unto them will I give in mine house and within my walls a place and a name better than of sons and of daughters: I will give them an everlasting name, that shall not be cut off.
keyVerses.significance: God promises honor and eternal remembrance to eunuchs who keep His covenant, highlighting His inclusive grace.

keyVerses.text: Even them will I bring to my holy mountain, and make them joyful in my house of prayer: their burnt offerings and their sacrifices shall be accepted upon mine altar; for mine house shall be called an house of prayer for all people.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God's intention for His temple to be a place of worship for all nations, not just Israel.

keyVerses.text: His watchmen are blind: they are all ignorant, they are all dumb dogs, they cannot bark; sleeping, lying down, loving to slumber.
keyVerses.significance: A strong rebuke of unfaithful leaders who fail to protect and guide God's people.
